results.title: Diastrophism: what moves mountains, what shapes the seas?
results.creator_credit: Richard Lukin, Universal Education and Visual Arts and Richard Slote
results.brief_description: Part of the “Science and the earth” series, this film provides an explanation of what scientists know about diastrophism, the forces which shape the earth’s surface. While earthquakes and volcanoes provide some information, much more is still required. Using animated maps and drawings the effects of earthquakes on the crust, mantle and core are shown. Such theories as whether the earth’s crust is floating on a sea of molten rock, whether the surface is shrinking or expanding in area, the origin of the continents and whether currents within the earth cause folding, are explored.

results.title: Diary of a teenage smoker
results.creator_credit: Atlantis Films, Health and Welfare Canada, Daphne Ballon, Rachel Low and Kari Skogland
results.brief_description: Young women talk about the damaging effects that cigarettes have had on their lives. This video was produced with the cooperation and involvement of teenagers themselves. They recount their reasons for taking up smoking, the physical, emotional and financial costs of addiction, and their struggles to give up the habit. Never didactic, this straightforward account of tobacco addiction also uses dramatised sequences to explore the ways in which the cigarette industry targets young female smokers. Canadian comedian, Sandra Shamus, appears in the video delivering a monologue on her battle to give up the “deadly weed”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Atlantis Films, Health and Welfare Canada, Daphne Ballon, Rachel Low and Kari Skogland

results.title: Diary of a student revolution
results.creator_credit: Morten Silverstein and National Educational Television
results.brief_description: An analysis of the question whether a University administration’s action in summoning the police force was an appropriate response to peaceful demonstrations on the Connecticut University campas. Trouble began at the University when industrial recruiting of students by Dow Chemical Company resulted in a confrontation between student activists and the University President.

results.title: Diary of a male whore
results.brief_description: Wael’s powerful, uncompromising short turns the body of its protagonist into a war zone, playing out the ongoing Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Loosely based on Moroccan author Mohamed Choukri’s For bread alone, a young Palestinian prostitute recalls his at times violent sexual awakening. As this all takes place during an encounter with an Israeli male client, Diary of a male whore also highlights the fraught state of the Israeli-Palestinian ‘peace’ process.

results.title: Diary for Timothy
results.creator_credit: Basil Wright, Crown Film Unit and Humphrey Jennings
results.brief_description: Timothy Jenkins was born on 3rd September 1944; this is a diary for him, a diary of the world at war into which he was born, and the transition period from war to peace. For civilians in these stirring times, life went on; a renaissance of interest in the arts was demonstrated by the enthusiasm accorded performances by such artists as John Gielgud and Dame Myra Hess in factory canteens and service hostels. The film ends with a question for Timothy: “What is he going to do when he grows up to make the world a better place for other babies who will be born into it?”. None of the characters or even events in this diary are fictitious- in fact, not a foot of this film was shot in the studios. It is a true record of old, unhappy, but not-so-far-off things made for one who was too young at the time to know what was happening, so that he may review these events when he was older. The commentary was written by E. M. Forster and spoken by Michael Redgrave.

results.title: Diana: story of a princess
results.creator_credit: Brook Lapping Productions, Sally Brindle, Nick Ward, Phil Craig and Janice Sutherland
results.brief_description: This four part television series is adapted from the book of the same name, retracing the life and mixed fortunes of Diana, Princess of Wales. The four part series features extensive interviews including: Diana’s staff, the press, royal biographers, photographers, friends, lovers, former colleagues as well as James Hewitt, Trevor Rhys-Jones and numerous people that Diana had met on tour. The documentary uses fictional “recreations” of certain scenes, voice-over narration and television footage to trace Diana’s life. Episode one: Diana’s life pre-royal marriage, her parents, birth, childhood, school years, employment in child care, engagement and marriage to Prince Charles, the rise of her popularity with the press. Episode 2: Ascendency of Diana’s fame and the press’s obsession with her, eclipsing Charles, cracks in the Royal marriage, the affair between Camilla and Charles, Diana’s popularity with the people and common touch. Episode 3: Diana’s affair with James Hewitt, the rival biographies, the Charles and Diana TV interviews, the divorce, Camilla gate, Diana gate, the rival camps and press obsession with the unravelling of the monarchy. Episode 4: Diana’s post-divorce suitors, fame in America, charity work with victims of landmines and AIDS, the press’s hounding of her, her romance with Dodi Al Fayed, death in Paris and subsequent public mourning of her life.

results.title: Diana: amputee
results.creator_credit: WGBH Educational Foundation, Janet Weaver and Rebecca Eaton
results.brief_description: A delightful study of a young girl who underwent a leg amputation because of a cancerous tumour. Shows how she learnt to cope with her disability and adjusted to her surroundings learning to ski on one leg at Darby Dogue Farm, Concord, Massachusetts.

results.title: Diana and me
results.creator_credit: Matt Carroll, Village Roadshow Pictures, Pratt Film Productions and David Parker
results.brief_description: In this fish-out-of-water comedy Toni Collette plays Diana Spencer, a down-to-earth rural girl who shares a birthday with her namesake, Princess Diana. After entering a competition in “Woman’s Day”, Spencer is overjoyed to win a five day trip to London for two and meet the Princess in person. Diana’s chance of a lifetime, however, is botched when a paparazzi photographer, scrambling for position, has them both evicted from the soiree. Thus begins a journey of self-discovery and identity for Spencer who not only falls for the photographer but also starts to question the worth of her life back in Australia and relationship with her working class fiancee. Filmed just prior to Princess Diana’ death, some scenes seem eerily prophetic such as the paparazzi stalking the Princess in a dangerous car chase. “Diana and me” proffers an exploration of the media machine that feeds off rumour and innuendo, and our culture’s fixation with the lives of celebrities; ultimately though the film is a romance, and timing of the subject matter aside, it is a fairly drab one at that, which draws on cultural stereotypes to lay the foundation for conflict (cultural and romantic) and its subsequent resolution.

results.title: Diamonds are forever (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation, Albert R. Broccoli, Harry Saltzman, Guy Hamilton and Ken Adam
results.brief_description: After bowing out in “You only live twice”, Sean Connery reprised his role as James Bond in “Diamonds are forever”, his second last outing as British Secret Service agent 007. From the diamond mines of South Africa, numerous caches of goods are going missing, making authorities fear that the market is in danger of being flooded. Bond is assigned to unravel the identity of the mystery stockpiler by going undercover as Peter Franks, a crook who is a part of a smuggling ring. A typically labyrinthine plot sends Bond to Amsterdam and then Las Vegas, chasing the recipient of a large diamond delivery whilst enjoying the charms of fellow smuggler Tiffany Case (Jill St John). Bond’s nemesis, Ernst Stavros Blofeld, returns planning to use the diamonds in a satellite that will allow him to hold the world for ransom. Bond survives his own cremation as well as encounters with memorable killers Mr Wint and Mr Kidd, a diabolical pair of lovers with a deadpan sense of humour, and two lethal martial arts gymnasts, Bambi and Thumper, who give Bond a going over. Thrills include a car chase in Las Vegas with numerous cops in pursuit and a ride in a moon buggy through the Nevada desert.

results.title: Diamonds
results.creator_credit: De Beers Consolidated Mining and Guild House Films
results.brief_description: Millions of tons of gravel and sand are sifted and washed in the search for diamonds in South Africa. In London the diamonds are cleaned and sorted according to size, shape, color and clarity. Most are used in industry but the finest are kept for jewellery. This age old craft of designing and making jewellery is shown as a delicate and unique work of art.
